title: Relative Bearings, Total Correction, Distance Off

questions.question: What is the relationship between magnetic bearing from an aircraft to a point, magnetic heading, and relative bearing to the point?
questions.answer: Aircraft heading + relative bearing = magnetic bearing to the point.

questions.question: Relative bearing is the angle between the __________ of the aircraft and a straight line from the aircraft to a point.
An object with a relative bearing of 090° is off the (right/left) wing of the aircraft.
An object directly off the tail of the aircraft has a relative bearing of __________°.

You're flying from A to B on a heading of 070°. After some time you notice A has a relative bearing of 170°, meaning it is (in front/behind) and to the (right/left). What is the bearing to A? What is the bearing from A? What is the TMG and your drift?
questions.answer: Behind. Right. 240°M. 060°M. TMG is 060°. Drift is 10° left (port).

questions.question: At position B, your relative bearing to the destination C is 005°. If your current heading is 070°, what is your bearing to C? Upon reaching B, you calculate a track error (TE) of 10° port. What is the TC required to reach C?

The track between A and B is 040°T. You've computed a heading of 026°M, variation is 21°E. While enroute you establish that A bears 176°R, and B bears 351°R. What is the new magnetic heading to make good B?
The required track from C to D is 119°M;. Variation is 21°E, deviation is 3°W. Your heading is 127°C. Enroute, C bears 168°R, and D bears 003°R. What is the required heading to make good D?
questions.answer: 139°M, or 160°T. Requires checking deviation for 139°M to obtain compass heading.
